wateringPrinciples: Check soil moisture before watering — stick a finger 2–3 cm into the soil.
Less frequent, deep watering is usually better than frequent shallow watering.
Drainage is critical: use pots with drainage holes and well-draining soil.
sunlightPrinciples: Bright indirect light is best for most houseplants.
Avoid harsh midday sun for broad-leaf plants (it can scorch leaves).
Rotate pots regularly so plants grow evenly.
fertilizerPrinciples: Feed actively-growing plants during spring and summer, reduce in fall/winter.
Use balanced houseplant fertilizer and follow label dilution.
Flush the soil occasionally to avoid salt buildup from fertilizers.
warning: Always adapt guidelines to your specific environment (humidity, temperature, pot size).

watering.method: water thoroughly until it drains, then let top 1–2 inches of soil dry
watering.notes: Tolerant of occasional missed waterings; avoid sitting in water.

sunlight.notes: Yellowing leaves may indicate too much direct sun or overwatering.

fertilizing.notes: Use half the recommended strength for sensitive plants.

plants.name: Snake Plant (Sansevieria / Dracaena trifasciata)

watering.method: allow soil to dry completely between waterings
watering.notes: Extremely drought-tolerant; overwatering is the most common problem.

sunlight.notes: Survives in low light but grows faster in bright indirect light.

commonIssues: brown leaf tips (low humidity or buildup)

plants.name: Fiddle Leaf Fig (Ficus lyrata)

watering.method: water thoroughly until it drains; keep soil slightly moist but not soggy
watering.notes: Sensitive to overwatering and sudden changes in environment.

sunlight.notes: Needs consistent bright light—look for new growth as a sign of health.

fertilizing.notes: Reduce frequency in winter; prune to encourage bushier growth.

commonIssues: brown spots from overwatering or pests
leaf drop from drafts or sudden moves

watering.method: keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged; wilting is an early sign of thirst
watering.notes: Will droop dramatically when thirsty but recovers quickly after watering.

sunlight.notes: Direct sun can scorch leaves; does well in filtered light.

fertilizing.notes: Too much fertilizer causes brown leaf tips.

plants.name: Spider Plant (Chlorophytum comosum)

watering.method: water when top inch of soil is dry; avoid letting it sit in water
watering.notes: Prefers slightly moist soil; adaptable to many conditions.

sunlight.notes: Direct sun may bleach leaf stripes.

commonIssues: brown tips from fluoride in water or overfertilizing

watering.method: soak and dry method: water deeply then allow soil to dry out completely
watering.notes: Use very well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes.

sunlight.hours: 6+ (many prefer several hours of direct sun)
sunlight.notes: Slow growth in low light; sun-adapt slowly to avoid sunburn.

fertilizing.notes: Less is more — overfertilizing leads to leggy growth.
